The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. The San Jose/Evergreen Community College District, through Workforce Institute, has been awarded a $465,062 Responsive Training Fund grant by the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office/Economic and Workforce Development.  The award is intended to develop and deliver leading edge training in integrated project delivery (IPD) for facilities professionals as well as create a virtual repository of IPD resources including industry information and templates for workplace use. Services will be provided in partnership with the International Facilities Management Association of Silicon Valley (IFMA), the Building Owners and Managers Association of Silicon Valley (BOMA), Salas O’Brien, Fenwick and West LLP, Western Allied Mechanical Inc., Dome Construction, and San Jose City College. The grant will fund the establishment of an IPD Knowledge Center, which will be a centralized virtual clearing house for IPD training, IPD lab access, and web-based professional resources. Short term IPD training will include hands on applications for facilities professionals in the greater Silicon Valley area who are currently under pressure to learn IPD as a requirement to generate better building performance.
 
The IPD program, specifically requested by IFMA, is directly responsive to industry need for a technology-based approach to facilities management. Regional facilities management professionals will access the skills and tools they need to create better building performance in Silicon Valley.
 
The grant will provide funding for a full-time Project Supervisor, 40% contracts assistant, and 50% senior networking technician over the grant term.

items.item_details:
Background - On January 25, 2011,  In accordance with BP 2745, the Board of Trustees initiated its annual self evaluation process.  Trustees Cruz, Lease and Okamura were appointed as a committee of the board to work with staff in the development of a process and criteria for evaluation.  On March 8, the committee reported on a  proposed process using  a survey methodology that would focus on two areas: (1) Board Operations and (2) Shared Accreditation Findings.  On May 10 the committee reported on the findings of the survey and proposed the development of a workplan based on the findings designed to build on the strengths of the Board and to address areas of weakness.  
	 
Two meetings were set aside to engage the full Board on the completion of a workplan, including the establishment of timelines and priorities. These meetings were scheduled on August 23, 2011 and September 10, 2011.  The first meeting focused on areas having direct bearing on the “Six Shared Recommendations” included in the 2010 Accreditation Review and that required Board action including: Planning, Board's Role, Chancellor Relations, Financial and Ethics. The second meeting addressed: Mission and Values, Community Engagement and Advocacy, Knowledge of Programs and Issues, Institutional Effectiveness, and Ethics.
	 
A workplan including 10 priorities for board action emerged using the “dashboard format.”  The workplan is attached to this document.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees formally approve the proposed workplan, including the projects and deadlines to implement each of the ten priorities.

The Utilities Infrastructure project at EVC is currently in construction.  During the on-going project, which includes replacement of the ITSS Data Center cooling system, the breaker that serves the ITSS UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply) system failed.  Following investigation, it was determined that the breaker was sized too small to accommodate the required loads, and that there had been an unsafe installation from long ago.  A temporary repair has been provided by an electrician.  
	 
In order to provide a safe, reliable operation of servers and network equipment in the ITSS Data Center, the electrical services currently in operation will need to be upgraded. 
	 
Thermal Mechanical is the contractor for the Utilities Infrastructure project, and they have submitted Change Order #2 in the amount of $17,141 to provide the necessary upgrades for a safe installation of the planned replacement of the ITSS air conditioning system.

items.item_details: On October, 21, 2011, the Board of Trustees received a letter from Senator Joseph Simitian, Eleventh Senate District, urging adoption of a resolution in support of his SCR 5, which would allow school districts, community college districts, and county offices of education to pass a parcel tax with a 55 percent majority vote rather than the currently required two-thirds. Senator Simitian stated that funding for K-14 education does not look promising. American Recovery and Reinvestment Act funds have dried up as well as the one-time tax increases from the Budget Act of 2009, which have expired. K-14 education funds have been reduced by billions of dollars. Therefore, it is imperative that we do all we can to alleviate the financial stress that California schools are experiencing.  It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution 110811-3.

The Association of Community College Trustees (ACCT) 42nd Annual Leadership Congress was held from October 12 – 15 in Dallas, Texas.  Approximately 1,200 community college trustees, presidents, and leaders gathered.  Trustees Mayra Cruz, Balbir Dhillon, Jeffrey Lease and Chancellor Rita Cepeda were in attendance.
	 
Immediately prior to the ACCT Leadership Congress, on October 11 and 12, ACCT convened the Symposium on Student Success: Generating a Policy Agenda, as a follow-up to last year's Summit on College Completion.  America's leaders in higher education, including trustees, presidents, and educators, as well as nationally recognized experts, researchers, and representatives from national membership associations, deliberated on the challenges to college completion and how to combine resources in order to identify the means by which to achieve the goal of improved college completion rates throughout the United States. Trustee Jeffrey Lease represented our District as a participant in the symposium.  
	 
The purpose of this item is to provide a brief synopsis of the major outcomes resulting from the Annual Congress and to present a draft policy agenda for student success urging this Board to join trustees nationwide in the review and adoption of some or all portions of this policy.

On September 26, the Board received a presentation on SJECCD’s redistricting process from Thomas Griffin from the Griffin Law Offices.  Dr. Griffin gave a presentation on the 2010 Census data and discussed its impact on SJECCD current district boundaries. Dr. Griffin provided a demographic report of each trustee area. He reviewed the 1 Person 1 Vote Rule, principles of the Voting Rights Act and those portions of the Education Code requiring that all school districts redraw their trustee areas after the federal census. Dr. Griffin also introduced the principle of 1% variance between and among contiguous trustee areas.  In other words, that we draw district boundaries that distribute the population in our service area within 1% of each other.  
	 
Following the presentation and after some discussion the board provided the following direction for the subsequent steps in the process:
	 
Review principles established by the Board of Trustees during the last redistricting effort in 2001 and integrate these same principles in the proposed options to be brought back to the Board (the overarching concern here is not to disadvantage minority communities and to support the election of a diverse board)
GPS maps of proposed options should include major traffic arteries to make it easier to determine when a trustee area begins and ends and to compare and contrast with the current boundaries.
Present clear timelines between the next presentation (first formal public hearing) and the end of the process
Identify outreach efforts to inform district constituents (voters) of the process underway at SJECCD and opportunities for public input.
